Text.Value: Both his magic and political sway are forces to be reckoned with.
There's every chance you'll die on the road.
You are looking at Lorroakan's newest apprentice.

EditorData.NodeContext: Excited, Eyes light up. This is his dream. He believes he is DESTINED for this.

Text.Value: What's so special about Baldur's Gate? Everyone here is so focused on it.
You are in for a treat, my otherworldly friend. There is no city in the Realms like Baldur's Gate.

EditorData.NodeContext: Excited

Text.Value: Merely planning ahead. Besides, never hurts to befriend a wizard.
In that case, it is I you should befriend.
Hold on. I'm not sure about this Lorroakan.
I'll be warmly received, besides. You are looking at Lorroakan's newest apprentice.
I've admired Lorroakan for years. Never dreamed he'd answer my letter.

EditorData.NodeContext: Eyes light up as he discusses his hero. He looks and sounds younger in this moment. Pure enthusiasm and excitement.

Text.Value: Forgive me. Of course someone like you wouldn't know.

EditorData.NodeContext: You think you're being kind but you're just being a condescending dick

Text.Value: Bah. I couldn't abandon her. No matter how prestigious the apprenticeship.

EditorData.NodeContext: This clearly bothers you much more than you are trying to show. You love Lia but it pains you not to be in Baldur's Gate.

Text.Value: There are many things I feel I should know... but I don't.
My apprenticeship with Lorroakan begins shortly. I cannot be late.

EditorData.NodeContext: Ibid.

Text.Value: Few can match me - in either magic or talent.
I have been offered an apprenticeship by none other than Lorroakan.
You don't understand.

EditorData.NodeContext: Player has asked why the hurry to the city. His career and his magic is more important to him than his life. This apprenticeship means EVERYTHING to him.

Text.Value: Common gossip! The by-products of ignorance and jealousy.
I couldn't agree more.

EditorData.NodeContext: Arrogant and haughty

Text.Value: Yes - that Lorroakan. The greatest wizard in Baldur's Gate.

EditorData.NodeContext: xcited, Eyes light up. This is his dream. He believes he is DESTINED for this.

Text.Value: It is if we end up dead.

EditorData.NodeContext: Disgusted and impatient

Text.Value: In that case, I'd very much appreciate it if you could arrange an introduction should we reach the city.
We need to go. We have a more pressing problem, remember?
Few can match him in terms of raw power and talent. Until now, that is.

EditorData.NodeContext: Smug and arrogant. He is powerful and he is talented. He's just smug about it.

Text.Value: But I've worked myself to the bone for this. Few can match me - in either magic or talent.

EditorData.NodeContext: Determined even as he's sounding overconfident. He has truly has worked his ass off to get here.

Text.Value: From its sights, to its smells, to the fortunes you can make. I myself am set to make history there...

EditorData.NodeContext: very much enjoying the sound of your own voice

Text.Value: Worrying won't help. I'm sure you'll be fine.
Perhaps the right master can rid you of your arrogance.
This place, and its people, are lost. The only way we'll make it to Baldur's Gate is on our own.
If you want to go, then go.
I've heard that name before. A young man, yes? Lives in Ramazith's Tower in the Upper City?
If it's powerful acquaintances you're after, you have to look no further than yours truly.
The very same!
Other than a desire to avoid impending death?
I don't believe in sacrifices for a lost cause.
Good idea: powerful acquaintances never hurt.
So eager to go to Baldur's Gate - do they even welcome tieflings?
His name is known far and wide, I see.

EditorData.NodeContext: Player says the know the wizard he speaks of. Happily surprised to see.

Text.Value: And I think one of her is quite enough in my life. Good day to you.
You're cheerful for someone about to abandon his kin.
We should have left by now. Damnation.

EditorData.NodeContext: Annoyed and frustrated. Having a little bit of a tantrum, to be honest. Not used to not getting his way.

Text.Value: Never heard of him. Who is he?
I wonder what Lorroakan will have me do first? Complex magic, no doubt.
Is this Lorroakan of Ramazith's Tower?
Leave on your own. Why wait?
I can spare but a moment - Baldur's Gate awaits! Oh, I can almost smell the city.

EditorData.NodeContext: Leaving for Baldur's Gate after a hell of an argument but isn't bothered. Excited to be leaving and seems oblvious to that fact that Lia is next to him, SEETHING.

Text.Value: As if I would be found in such a place. No, I am destined for greater things.

EditorData.NodeContext: Player

Text.Value: We're leaving for Baldur's Gate. And we will make it.
You're doing the right thing. The tieflings need help.
You're doing the right thing. The others need help.
That is tempting...
You don't wish to help your fellow tieflings?
Are you always this selfish?
I'm to study under Lorroakan, you see.
Yes - that Lorroakan. The greatest wizard in Baldur's Gate. This will change everything.
Please - this is confidence, not arrogance.

EditorData.NodeContext: Player has told him not be cocky. Dismissive of their words. He's good and he knows it.

Text.Value: Why the rush to leave?
Don't be fooled by mere gossip! The by-products of ignorance and jealousy.
And what about us? There's every chance we've doomed ourselves by helping these people.
And we will make it. I know it.
Standing by your people is never a mistake.
... as apprentice to Lorroakan, the greatest wizard in Baldur's Gate. This will change everything.
You're leaving? Good. Save your own skin to fight another day.
More than most. A few strangers may stare - but they'll keep their daggers sheathed.
I cannot leave Lorroakan waiting.
Hold on. Why are you so eager to reach the city?
In years to come, you will boast of this meeting - I can assure you. May we meet again in Baldur's Gate, my friend.
Of course I will be. As if there was any doubt.

EditorData.NodeContext: Arrogant and haughty

Text.Value: Run, then. And run scared.
What? You don't know of him? I've admired him for years.

EditorData.NodeContext: Pride and awe in his voice. He's clearly imagining himself in the same position.

Text.Value: I think I've heard stories about Lorroakan. Bad ones.
I've heard stories about Lorroakan - not all of them good.
You sound excited.
You made the right choice. This place isn't safe.
Tch. You're as bad as Lia.
... but I could never leave Lia behind, as irksome as she may be.
Our best chance to make it to Baldur's Gate is on our own. This place is lost.
We must leave soon. My apprenticeship with the wizard begins shortly.
I've forgotten much. But I could never forget the aroma of the Outer City.
The aroma of the Outer City is pretty unique.
Quite right. Lia can be stubborn at times.
Why burden yourself with companions? You should slip away - alone.
The names 'Rolan' and 'Lorroakan' will be known far and wide. You'll see.
If we stop and help every wounded foal, we'll end up dead, or worse. Lia just can't see it.
I've heard the Elfsong Tavern makes a mean bowl of stew.
Please. I can handle myself. It's others that are the issue.
But thank you for your concern. It was touching.

EditorData.NodeContext: Sarcasm. He's irritated by what he perceives as the player's criticism.

Text.Value: We will end up fodder for some goblin's blade - all because Lia insists on helping every wounded foal we see.
Common gossip! The by-products of ignorance and jealousy.
I've heard he's quite the scoundrel.
Of course he is! The greatest spellcaster along the Sword Coast. As if I'd settle for a lesser mentor.
Instead we're just sitting here - practically begging to be attacked. Staying is a mistake.
My Thunderwave will make quick work of any goblin - just you wait.
If only she understood. The longer we wait, the longer the horrors of the wilds imperil us.
Baldur's Gate isn't going anywhere. Why the hurry?
Rest assured, the names 'Rolan' and 'Lorroakan' will be known to you soon enough. You'll see.

EditorData.NodeContext: Dismissive shrug. Stating this like a fact.

Text.Value: Word in Waterdeep has it he's a bit of a cad. But you say he's an accomplished wizard?
Why the rush to leave?
Well, you're here, aren't you? You can help them if you want.

Synopsis: This occurs after the argument with Lia. If they're leaving for Baldur's Gate he's pretty relaxed about the argument and dismissive of Lia and her concerns. If they're staying in the grove, he's furious and is convinced they'll die here.
